Posts.Content: Thanks for posting.  I too, missed everyone after treatment.  I go back once a month to get my port flushed and when I take my seat in the recliner and lean it back, I feel like I'm home again.  My main nurse is also a brest cancer survivor, so she really had my back.  I thought I must be the only one that felt that way so, of course, I've never admitted it to anyone.  I since then joined Curves and exercise there.  It's being a Godsend.  I've thought about becoming a volunteer, so I could give back some of what was given to me, but so far, I'm leaving it to the staff and getting to know me again.  Joining a good breast cancer support group is also very beneficial.  No you're not nuts.  :-D  We need to let go and let the nurses care for the women that come after us.  There are many, unfortunately.  Take care.  Linda
Posts.Title: miss hospital staff and chemo staff

Posts.Content: So sorry.  My advice is Stay in the Moment.  Enjoy each day as much as possible as you two take this journey.  Be kind to yourself and pull out your gratitude list when the pain is too much.  Sometime's our loved ones are taken away from us without any extra time.  Get right back in the moment when you stray away.  I have to do this over and over.  And remember all we really have is this moment.  When I was dx in 1999, I was sure the next funeral I would go to was mine.  Boy, did I get that wrong.  Give your Mom a hug and tell it was from me.  And here's one for you.  Remember, we are never alone.  Hugs and prayers, Linda
Posts.Title: Lost, Alone, and in Need of Advice

Posts.Content: Has anybody made 5 years on this drug.  It seems the side effects are just too much.
Posts.Title: Anastrolle

Posts.Content: Hi, Sorry you are having bad side effects also.  (my side effects were HORRIBLE hot flashes with HORRIBLE tingling in all my joints, couldn't sleep, irritated beyond belief) etc.  I stopped.  I couldn't handle it.  I took all the chemo, all the radiation, surgeries with good results.  But when I tried the meds for 6 mos.  I said no more.  My dr is doing blood work every 3 mos with good results so far.  My next blood work is in about 2 mos.  If it's in the normal range, he said I could have my port removed if I want.  He also said, I gave it my best in trying the drugs.  He also said, "there is no guarantee the drugs will keep the ca away and he also commented, "not taking them will mean it comes back.  My lifestyle, age, and other health issues helped me make a the decision to stop.  Does it haunt me sometimes?  Yes, it does but everyday feeling more back normal I forget about it.  It's a heck of a decision none of us should have to go through.  Evidently, there is enough proof that taking the drugs do have better outcomes, but will cancer be my demise?  I don't know.  There's a lot of other things out there taking lives every day.  Hopefully there's anoher pill on the way with less side effects.  If there is good support in the town you live, that might be really helpful.  Take care and hope you can get comfortable with whatever decision you make.  That's where staying in the moment helps.
Posts.Title: Glad I Found This site

Posts.Content: I was grateful to search and find this site also.  I am also 64. I was dx with stage 2-3  breast cancer, estrogen positive 93%.  The 93% is why my dr really wanted me to be able to tolerate one of the hormone drugs.  I tried 2 (6 months) and the quality of life for me was not tolerable.  So, since stopping the drug, I have joined a gym changed my eating habits.  I finally feel some sort of normalcy.  I also  know several women personally that can tolerate the meds.  Not clear if your concerns are the know drug sideffects or the effects you are experiencing.  If I could of tolerated them, I would of kept taking them.  I try to live in the moment and enjoy this day.  The exercise (Curves) and eating tons of steamed veggies and fresh fruit are being a pleasant journey for me.  Am I cramming for the finals, maybe, but it's never to late if I can stay in the moment.  That's all we really have.  The best to you.
Posts.Title: Glad I Found This site

Posts.Content: I didn't re-read my post but what I meant was:  my doctor said if I stop taking it, does NOT mean it will come back.  Never considered myself brave, but maybe we all are.  Otherwards there are no guarantees either way.  Taking it or not taking it.  That's where I had to consider my Quality of life, not quantity.   The reason I tried 2 drugs was because some people can tolerate tylenol and some can tolerate advil so I gave two a try and I guess #3 isn't out yet.   Bottom line:  I tried two and not worth it to me.  I was too sick taking a drug that has no guarantees.   Hopefully, what ever you and your doctor decides we will still be  posting 20 years from now.   Regarding my port, that's how they administered my chemo 5 days a week for I think at least 6 weeks. I hope the best for you and that you can tolerate any side effects.  They ask that  you take it for 5 years.  I've also read that the results are promising that if you can tolerate it another 5 years even better.   God Bless You and he is the one in charge.  I'm trying to do the footwork the best I can.
Posts.Title: Glad I Found This site

Posts.Content: Medical cannabis is sold in my state.  They sell food products with cannabis as a main ingredient, so you don't have to smoke it if you don't want to.  You can also do your own baking or cooking, probably cheaper.  I've injested all 3 ways.  I'm in remission as far as I know today.  Today is all we have.  Remission is a nice word, but I really don't think I'll ever be back as good as it was for me.  I go to Curves and exercise and I've even got wet doing water aerobics (once, for far).  I care for myself and I'm responsible for 2 doggies.  Actually, my two doggies play a very important role in me surviving one day at a time.  That in itself is very nerve racking.  With all that said, I finally felt good enough to mop my kitchen floor.  Well, while pushing that mop, I injured my hip muscle?.  I didn't fall, slip, just twisted the wrong way.  That was a week ago, and it gets better and then after walking with my dogs, the whole left side aches and burns.  Sometimes foot, sometimes knee, etc.  Even my neck got crick in it today.  It hurt.  Ok, so I did injest a minute amount of cannabis, Advil isn't cutting it right now.  Do I still have pain?  Yes, but I can sit and type.  It makes my body want to stretch.  I'm 64 1/2.  I'm female with breast ca and I'm finally growing some balls.
Posts.Title: medication vs. cannibis

Posts.Content: I actually had a pain free, side-effect free moment the other day.  I forgot how that felt.  It was short lived, but a reminder that maybe this is all worth it.   When I was going thru chemo and rad, I reported every side effect, and they seemed to come up with remidies that helped.  We have to have help with this, so let them know because we are all different.  I remember not having the strength to stand long enough to get a shower, and they started hydrating me on a regular basis.  That sure helped.  When I went in weak again it was my potassium level being too low.  I learned Lay's potato chips have a good amt of potassium, so I could munch on those when baking a potato was just too much effort.  Seems like a big blur, but still so real.  I remember diarrhea being so bad one night, I screamed bloody murder while sitting on the toilet.  I think it helped.  I was ready to call 911.  Living alone allows screaming, but being alone is sure scarey at times.  I'm 64 and wanted my Mom.  My chemo nurse became my best friend during that time.  So let them know what's going on and Hang in there, it's what we do.
Posts.Title: Feel crap!

Posts.Content: Hi.    I tried arimidex (sp) for 5 months and could not handle my side effects.  My dr switched me to tamoxifin and I tried it maybe 2 months and said no more.  My dr.  Said:  You know you've tried and just can't tolerate it.  Then he said:  Taking either drugs do not guarantee the ca will not come back, and not taking the drugs doesn't not mean you won't stay in remission.  I'm 64 and was hoping I could take them since I'm 93% estrogen positive.  But they are not for me.  Even my mood changed from very passive to down right wanting to hurt people.  Maybe it was because I couldn't sleep.  I even tried taking a Valium with them, but then I was a zomby and could sleep 24/7 and didn't really care.  I've been off the meds for 29 days.  I'm exercising and eating a very healthy diet.  I still have hot flashes at this point, but all the other side effects have subsided.  At this moment, I'm pretty comfortable not taking anymore meds.  The best to us all.
Posts.Title: Not sure if I want to continue tamoxifen

Posts.Content: One day at a time, and staying in the moment.  Putting  one foot in front of the other.  Attitude and nutrition and God above.  All we have is this moment.  The best to you and your family.  I am also trying to practice what I preach.  Linda
Posts.Title: how long does a person survive once cancer has spread into different parts of the body

Posts.Content: Hello, I too was dx with stage 2.  I did chemo and radiation before the prescription drugs.  I've tried both drugs and have stopped taking the second one (tamoxifin) 15 days ago.  I see my oncologist in two days and see how my new lab results are. I'm 64 and hoping my labs stay in the normal range, With both drugs I took them about 7 months in total.  I still have occasional hot flashes and still not sleeping well, but feel much better.  I also have a friend who's been able to tolerate them and work full time for 3 years.  It's different for everyone.   Will the pain all be gone, who knows?  I've had pain you have described many years before breast cancer dx in 2012.  My decision to stop was when my personality changed, not for the better.  I was angry and frustrated all the time.  That has really subsided also.  I guess it's quality vs quantity.  The best to you.
Posts.Title: hello all from Tokyo

Posts.Content: My lump didn't show up on either two, and the radiologist said it was a wait and see.  I was so relieved, but my doc said, oh no it's not.  A bx show Stage 2-3 estrogen positive breast cancer with mets running around.  I'd take a small scar anyday.
Posts.Title: lump doesn't show up on mammogram or ultrasound, do I need an excision biopsy?

Posts.Content: Hi, Yes, that is a big issue for us women.  I went ahead and cut it really, really short and then I buzzed it.  A friend of mind shaved his head for me.  Now I keep it really short and really like it.  Bald can be beautiful.  You are right, it not the worst thing in cancer world, but it can mess with your head (no pun intended).  What I do know, when when I was my weakest, it sure helped not to have to wash and do my hair.  Hang in there.  This too shall pass.  Linda   ps American Cancer Society also supplies wigs for free.  I couldn't wear the hot thing.  A local beauty shop fixed it for me for free.  I came out looking like Dolly Parton.  Try to have some fun with it.  Remember, ATTITUDE and nutrition are very important.  Hugs and prayers
Posts.Title: Scared about losing hair

Posts.Content: Stay in the moment.  What helps me with the waiting game, is if it's on a week-end or something I have to wait on, I really try to let it go until I can get back on the horse and take care of business.  All we actually have is this moment anyway.  Make the best (it's hard).  Thoughts and prayers.  LindaG
Posts.Title: What next....
